com:
Welcome to /diy/, a place to:

Post and discuss /diy/ projects, ask questions regarding /diy/ topics and exchange ideas and techniques.

Please keep in mind:
- This is a SFW board. No fleshlights or other sex toys.
- No weapons. That goes to /k/ - Weapons. The workmanship and techniques involved in creating objects which could be used as weapons or the portion of a weapons project that involves them (e.g., forging steel for a blade, machining for gunsmithing, what epoxy can I use to fix my bow) may be discussed in /diy/, but discussing weapon-specific techniques/designs or the actual use of weapons is disallowed. Things such as fixed blade knives or axes are considered tools, things such as swords, guns or explosives are considered weapons.
- No drugs or drug paraphernalia (See Global Rule 1). If you want to discuss something that could involve such things (e.g., carving a tobacco pipe from wood) that's fine, but make sure it's /diy/ related and doesn't involve drugs or it will result in deletion/ban.

Helpful links:
https://sites.google.com/site/diyelmo/
http://www.engineeringtoolbox.com/

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
Some friendly suggestions for posting:
- First ask Google, then ask /diy/. Your question will probably be better received if you do so.
- List available resources (tools, materials, budget, time, etc.)
- Try to use pictures and explain the goal, if possible
- Be patient, this is a slow board; your thread will be around for days.
- Share your results! /diy/ loves to see problems solved and projects completed!

name: Anonymous
com:
How would I go about making my own cases, keycaps, buttons, and switches with printed lettering, logos, etc. for my electronics projects (a handheld computer, for example)? I want to have a similar level of quality to at least 1980s consumer products, not perfect but at least good looking and robust.

A 3D printer would be an obvious starting point, but some of the particulars like the brushed aluminum surfacing or a folded sheet metal case would require different tools and processes. What are some tools I'd need, and what processes would be required to achieve this kind of build quality?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
For more "quality" fit-and-finish like brushed aluminum surfaces or that calculator you posted; the calculator's case is stamped aluminum, a process too costly in tooling to make economical for small projects. It is also why nearly everything is injection molded plastic cases today. You can look at laser or water jet cutting thin plates of brushed aluminum as a type of manufacturing for a panel or enclosure face.

If you want to really get into crazy DIY rabbit hole expertise, check out Ben Krasnow's "Applied Science" channel on youtube.

Good luck anon, I hope the best success for your projects, post results sometime.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2518654
>>2518656
>>2518658
I'm in Australia, so sourcing stuff like keycaps and silicone might be a bit trickier, but I'll see what I can find.

For the metal fabrication I could probably work with what I've got in my shed, but the main question I need an answer to is how manufacturers put text and logos on their products? Is there a specific process that can be done at home to achieve the same results?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2518734
Silicone can be hard to get text and logos to stay on if done in fine detail by hand. You would have to find a silicon bonding paint or dye and then paint the reverse image in the mold and then pour over it, which might give some results you could try to refine.

You may be better off looking into labelling the faceplate of the button/switch/key/housing. In that case you can look at water transfer decals with a finishing coat (polyurethane?) to protect from rubbing off, silkscreening (lots of color choices), or laser engraving and then wiping in a color inlay in the etching (good for single color). Each different method has increased costs in tooling. "Applied Science" has a silkscreening video, and also you can see what "DIY silkscreen electronics" search yields.

Silkscreen is sometimes taught at community or continuing education centers, or whatever the equivalent might be called in Australia. Laser engravers are not too expensive depending on what you want. I've never done water decals on a finished product other than model airplanes/cars etc. but they are legitimately used in small batch productions.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2518734
Also, if you are having trouble sourcing silicone mix materials, try looking in your country's film industry sector; many of the silicone suppliers sell to that business because silicone, moldable foams, urethanes, polymer clay, etc. is used extensively in the film industry for prop making and character creation. Just a largely overlooked but super-specific niche DIY market to make fake items that look real for film.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2518599
Made some cases:
If plastics are okay, then vacuum form from acrylic or other sheet. It’s a really easy process and diy suitable, you just need a die that’s cnc cut or 3D printed.

For metal cases if you have an adequate press rubber pressing and stamping/punching is doable. You do need punches/dies. Standard shaped punches can be bought, but the dies for rubber pressing and stamping need to be CNC’d or otherwise manufactured from steel. For simple rectangular case an angle grinder could work though

com:
Where can I find a 100% complete explaination of how a modern CPUs is made, from sand to finished product?
I mean not a simple description like the ones you could find on YouTube, but a complete walkthrough with an accurate description of every single step, such that any moron could use it to build a functioning CPU entirely by himself (provided he had unlimited access to all necessary equipment and resources).

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2512665
>the steps are broken apart across different people and in different organizations and they run in parallel instead of one after another.
Look, I'm not an expert at chip manufacturing, but anyone with even a basic idea of the general process can tell that's bullshit.
CPUs are not made by combining various parts together like a house or a computer; CPUs come from 1 single monolithic piece progressively "carved" into a finished product, so it cannot be made in "parallel" like you say

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2513372
you're talking about a single phase of the construction of a CPU, the photolithography. the wafers used for this come from somewhere, ready to go. they're held in a stock to be fed into the machine. the photolithography machine itself has been invented and assembled and prepared and maintained. the chemicals used in the process have been prepared and are on-hand.
OP anon was asking about step-by-step "starting from sand" - this is all shit he would need to do manually and prior to the actual etching phase in his scenario that the established industry has the advantage of parallelizing by way of just buying the prepared materials.

>>2517799
for de-soldering, I would highly recommend using a solder sucker/pump like a goot GS-108 or TP-100 which will generally work much faster and stress the pads less from my experience especially for someone who never used solder wick b4.
also might want to watch these first before u start if u haven't soldered b4:
https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PL926EC0F1F93C1837

https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLBXXuFXCtmtqlamIEfu3lSTzM5t1k2cx_

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=M0wI-5YZQm4

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vpgMn88Qfjs

follow the steps and complete the primary check/repair, then you should go for a secondary diagnoses, which has 3 golden roles:

1. during this stage u will have to power up the board, the best way to power it is an isolation transformer, so the board is kept floating (galvanically isolated) this will reduce the risk of electrocution, also install a fast acting low current breaker or an incandescent lightbulb/heater or a fuse inline for added safety against short circuits accidental and otherwise, i personally use a 200w ceramic heater it if it glows i know there is a short and due to the PTC nature of the heater it limits the current enough to not cause catastrophic failure...
u could work on it on that state, but still i wouldn't recommend that for a beginner, so wear gloves and boots while working, and if u don't have access to an isolation transformer u have to use a GFCI/RDC outlet or breaker in line with circuit u are powering:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=olq9wdeNS4c

2.make sure yk where ur hands are!! keep ur hands off the board and the board always powered down at all times except during the test!!!


3. thou shalt check voltages, start from the primary side, since the voltages there are known for the most part, if they are in the ball park (+10v or -10v) its ok, any thing higher u should investigate the primary components

Already using the system on our current house. installed it all ourselves. we generate about 40% of our power. running since March.

>What printer should I buy? [Last updated 2022-11-19]
Under 250 USD: kingroon KP3L, Sovol sv01, Creality Ender 3 (v2), Anycubic Mega S
Under 500 USD: Qidi X-One2, Creality CR-10, Anycubic Vyper, Prusa Mini
Under 1000 USD: Prusa i3, Bambu Labs X1
Over 1000 USD: e3d toolchanger, Ultimaker, Qidi X-CF Pro, Build your own Voron, Rat Rig, Prusa XL (lol enjoy the wait)
SLA: Anycubic Photon, Elegoo Mars, Prusa SL1, Formlabs Form 3, Creality HALOT-ONE
Instead of buying a new printer, you could consider building your own: https://reprap.org/wiki/

https://www.thingiverse.com/
https://thangs.com/
https://grabcad.com/
https://google.com/
https://printables.com/
https://www.yeggi.com/

>What CAD software should I use?
Variants of professional parametric CAD programs such as Solidworks (lol paying for software), Fusion360, Inventor, Onshape, TinkerCAD, and AutoCAD may be free depending on your profession, level of piracy and definition of ''free''.
Most anons use Fusion360, but some /g/oobers prefer OpenSCAD or FreeCAD. If you want to do mesh free-forming and modeling, Blender is alright. Also while not necessarily a design program, Meshmixer (free) can be extremely useful for tweaking models to print.

com:
Has anyone installed crown molding before?

I work as a handyman and do mostly paint and drywall. Today a customer asked me to put up some crown molding. I said sure. After 2 hours and like 5 missed cuts, I just gave up and told the customer I could not do it.

Anyone worked with this shit? How do you get this thing down?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2518641

I charge depending on the challenges of what I’m doing. My rates go from $40 to $90 an hour.

But I never price by the hour, always a flat rate for the job needed

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
It's kind of like cutting your hair in the mirror and requires lots of patience and triple checking.
Easiest way with minimal risk of fuckups is doing it upside down using crown stops Iike in picrel.
HOWEVER orienting the cut correctly is only part of it and measurements are critical and easy to mess up.
One old trick to avoid that is to cut both sides of an inside and outside corner (4 pieces total) to use as guages...do the miters like in picrel then cut them all at 90° on the opposite end at an identical length from the long points, about 10"-12".
When you measure you can hold them up where the joints go and then put a mark at the square end.
The you just measure between those marks and add the combined length of the guage blocks and it's way more accurate than holding a tape.
It also lets you know how how square all the wall/ ceiling angles are and where you will need to make adjustments, before its too late.
Since those angles are rarely perfect another trick is to use a flat bar or stiff putty knife to gently pry and hold the moldings so the joints meet while you cross nail them to hold them there. When you're done you can caulk or shim any visible gaps and cut in the appropriate wall or ceiling color just to the edge of the molding, which gives a crisp line that hides any dippiness in the wall, and perfectly matched corners.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2518630
1) that's upside down
2) you can find the mounting angle of the crown and charts that tell you the miter and bevel setting on your saw to get the 45° cuts right

You can also buy adjustable jigs for nesting the crown on the saw (holds it up at the proper angle)

Then after you cut, you can adjust the pitch of the crown to get the corners to sit tightly

Then, if its white, you just caulk the corner with latex caulking or paintable silicone, dab the nails and paint

Practice on scrap first and put in at least an hour.

Before melting metal study modern options like Lord, 3M and other crash tested structural adhesives. They don't warp metal or risk hot spatter in places you can't put it out.

I've MIG, TIG and (love 'em) several "aircraft" style OA torches all of which work but adhesives can solve many problems with no heat distortion, and less corrosion risk if you live where that matters because you're not burning off inner paint or undercoat with heat.

com:
I've been having problems with muddy water in my ponds, when it rains it gets even worse. I get the water from a small river through gravity, the pipe is just submersed in it so there isn't any kind of filtration whatsoever. I am wondering if placing a layer of rock, clay pebbles or anything that would let the water through while keeping solids out would be a solution to this.

I know of the chemical treatments I could use to settle these solids but I don't want to use them, I've also been to fisheries that use huge sedimentation tanks to solve this. The setup I am thinking about doing is a dam with 3 walls which one would be porous and would filter the water that the pipe would then discharge in my ponds, the overflow would let branches and other debris continue down the river. Would the water still be muddy after this? I also know this works for people that make a series of filtration layers (rock, sand, charcoal, etc) for drinking water but the flow I need is considerable, so I can't have a trickle.

If it did work I would imagine I would need to clean it periodically but that wouldn't be a problem.
filename: collection of water from muddy river

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
Is this for drinking, or something like irrigation/fish ponds?
Sediments are picked up as the water moves quickly, and settle when the water slows down. So I'd first ask if you are using the most optimal access point to draw water. Are there areas of the river that are flowing more slowly (but not so slow that you have algae issues, I guess)? Are you able to modify the flow of the water at the point you are drawing from to optimize the speed? e.g. digging out the riverbed to increase the cross-sectional area and reduce the speed, or damming the river to expand it and slow it.

last_replies.name: Anonymous

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
Might be easier to just keep it muddy and clean your pool more often. Doubt the mid is bad for your fish.
You can use filters, but they will get clogged if you need a considerable flow. Damming will slow the water and allow sedimentation to happen.
The dam overflow will the be much cleaner. Triple dam even more do, but you'll end up having to clean your dams.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2516237
Look into rain gardens and sediment retention; Geosyntec has some documents regarding volume inflow reduction from geo engineering with rain gardens or bioengineered strata like you mentioned, both reduce sediment deposition by stabilizing the banks, please avoid chemical treatments if you can, and try some decorative shrubbery, cattails and lily pads, water demanding plants, and thin trees, you can even trim these regularly and the effect will still be observed. I can come back with some more resources but general keywords for more info would be the ones mentioned above as well as any study relating vegetation to reductions in watershed sediment load, retention ponding, and erosion or stream bank stabilization. Best of luck.

Acid reacts with and rapidly corrodes the surface of metal. Can be used in combination with a resist to make some sort of pattern or just applied generally to expose virgin metal, as for weld testing.

>What printer should I buy? [Last updated 2022-11-19]
Under 250 USD: kingroon KP3L, Sovol sv01, Creality Ender 3 (v2), Anycubic Mega S
Under 500 USD: Qidi X-One2, Creality CR-10, Anycubic Vyper, Prusa Mini
Under 1000 USD: Prusa i3, Bambu Labs X1
Over 1000 USD: e3d toolchanger, Ultimaker, Qidi X-CF Pro, Build your own Voron, Rat Rig, Prusa XL (lol enjoy the wait)
SLA: Anycubic Photon, Elegoo Mars, Prusa SL1, Formlabs Form 3, Creality HALOT-ONE
Instead of buying a new printer, you could consider building your own: https://reprap.org/wiki/

https://www.thingiverse.com/
https://thangs.com/
https://grabcad.com/
https://google.com/
https://printables.com/
https://www.yeggi.com/

>What CAD software should I use?
Variants of professional parametric CAD programs such as Solidworks (lol paying for software), Fusion360, Inventor, Onshape, TinkerCAD, and AutoCAD may be free depending on your profession, level of piracy and definition of ''free''.
Most anons use Fusion360, but some /g/oobers prefer OpenSCAD or FreeCAD. If you want to do mesh free-forming and modeling, Blender is alright. Also while not necessarily a design program, Meshmixer (free) can be extremely useful for tweaking models to print.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2518526
>Can we get a description of what's happening here?
Sure. I guess I should add some reference number. Essentially there are 3 circuits:
- the air circuit (hatched) that cools the mantle before being diluted with exhaust and then is fed into the reactor (bottom right)
- the wood gas circuit from the reactor going through tar absorbers and filter before going to the gas turbine, while being cooled by water
- the water circuit that goes in opposite direction to the wood gas circuit, picking up heat throughout the path, before being superheated in the spiral at the bottom of the reactor and then powers a steam turbine.

Lots of details (condencer, recuperator, waste extraction etc) are missing but I hope those are obvious anyway.
Wood in the first tar absorber is fed to the reactor through the yellow square chute at intervals, thus recycling the tar.

name: Anonymous
sub: How can I be sure this is tinned copper?
com:
My autism is making me paranoid. Today I received this 10AWG tinned copper silicone wire from Aliexpress. The reviews are good, the core/insulation measurements match or even outmatch the specs but you'll always get some retards in the reviews saying that this is not real tinned copper and that it's aluminium, silver, brass or whatever. But what if those retards are actually the smart ones and all the others got fooled?

Here is what I've done so far:
-Burned the shit out of some strands. Nothing gets brittle. Only thing that melts is the end of some of the strands, once they're cooled down they form a small ball at the end of the strand. Overall after many burns the conductor hasn't lost its thickness whatsoever.
-The burning definitely reveals some orange colors on the strands. You also get some yellowish and even greenish/blueish tints sometimes. Will post some shitty pics bellow.
-Scrapping strands with a knife doesn't reveal shit because they're just too small.
-Checked with my multimeter and I get 000.1Ω from one 5m wire but from what I understand this doesn't necessarily mean anything. Ideally you need a "4-wire measurement" thingy and I don't have one.
-Not the main subject but it's definitely silicone insulation, smells like shit out of the box and hasn't melted one bit from all my burning tests.

>but the multimeter test is fine

Multimeters are not accurate at low resistances. Anything lower than 1-2Ω should usually be treated as just a ballpark measurement, never even mind measurements below 100mΩ. You usually need a dedicated resistance meter for that kind of measurement, or to measure voltage across test points when using a constant-current source (which is what a resistance meter does, just with convenient packaging).

>>2518114
You don't want to boil because it weakens the bones. You cannot get good specimens doing that. You can buy some beetles and a tank or you could set the head outside on a balcony or something inside a mesh cage and let maggots eat some. For the water bucket putrefaction step you also want to set the bucket outside on a balcony or something. This really stinks. The whole process really smells. Don't do this inside your house or in an apartment. Wait for warmer weather. You will have trouble getting the death smell out of your home. Trying to think of how to change the water buckets without defiling your apartment. You may very well get the cops called on you or lose your lease for this. This is an outdoor activity.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
If you live in the city, you're going to have problems.

The best way would be to use a combination of what people above have mentioned. Find somewhere where you can leave it for a few weeks and let nature take its course. Obviously it needs to be secured to stop larger predators taking it. After most of the flesh etc. is gone, you want to soak it in a bucket of water for a while to get into all the nooks and crannies. Adding a small amount of dish soap will help things along. Take it out and give it a good scrub and change the water every week or so. At this stage the teeth may potentially come loose so make sure you don't loose any. The dish soap is essential for degreasing the bones. To get a nice white finish, soak them in a 1:3 mixture of hydrogen peroxide to water.

Under no circumstances boil them as this will only trap the fat inside the bone and make them rot and smell. It also undermines the structural integrity of the bone. Also never use bleach as this will also weaken the bone structure.

Finally join a Facebook group for bone collectors or taxidermists. There are lot's of great communities that are happy help and will teach you a thing or two.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2515777
Potassium nitrate isn't hard to produce. That's why it was in the original recipe for gunpowder. You can even make and purify it from scratch.

Potash can be produced by soaking wood ashes in water to make an impure potassium carbonate solution. Nitrates can be produced by giving microbes time to act on urine in sandy dirt. Potassium ions from potassium carbonate have a superior affinity for nitrate ions from mixed nitrates in soil, so you can easily grow pure potassium nitrate crystals by fractional crystallization from solutions in water.

I don't know about any laws about making it, especially in Europe, but from a practical perspective rather than a legal one, it's feasible to produce limited amounts of KNO3 if you have some suitable workspace. You can make larger amounts with animal manure, though urine seems cleaner and easier to work with.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2518027
To be clear, you can make quite a lot of potassium nitrate from your own urine. Nearly all of the nitrogen in protein you eat will end up in your urine, and be converted to nitrate by microbes if you're pissing in the sandbox.

If you eat 100g of protein daily, about 16g of that will be nitrogen, so if you get half your urine in the box, that'll be 8g of nitrogen per day. Nitrogen is about 1/7th the weight of potassium nitrate, so that gives 56g of potassium nitrate per day. Accounting for other losses, you can probably realistically produce about a pound of potassium nitrate every two weeks from your own urine, or a pound every week if you really go hard.

That's a whole lot of model rocket propellant or gunpowder for personal use.

I try to salvage all components, that have honestly saved me a fortune, some of my more complex projects used mosfets and h-bridge and even Z80 chips that are almost 50SARs (13.30USD) here, i think i mentioned this b4 but all the caps I used i got from an old trashed amp, most modern electronic components are fairly resilient and can handle moderate heat (100c-350c) in short intervals just fine, but i wouldn't say the same about board substrate, especially the older boards which use cotton paper resin composite or phenolic resins which really don't like the temperature getting above 380c for too long as they tend to puff up or crack or burn.
personally i use a manual solder pump and wick for most salvage work to not stress the board or component, but for stuff i really don't want to damage i have a a goot TP-100 de-soldering gun that I use for that stuff, its not ideal but at least i have some temperature control that I don't have with my soldering iron which tends to drift up as i am working from (~345c-430c) or even higher if not used for some time a while plugged in, which is usually not a problem when i am de-soldering for salvaging and idc about the pcb, but during rework it tents to be a pain to work around, a wet sponge helps knock the temp down 10 or so degrees but it is really hard to gauge the temp without constantly checking it with thermocouple. my iron is gr8 60% of the time when i am doing anything else, but just makes my life a nightmare in that other 40%(which is rework), it is a goot TQ-95 for reference.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2512241
>even the *shittiest* machines can hold ~.0001

That's about the limit of what you can do with a Hardinge super precision lathe in a climate controlled room. It's one thing to mic a shaft or a bore to tenths but another to actually have that precision in form and size. I'd bet that the majority of used lathes in standard shops struggle to even hold that kind of roundness. And no, you can't measure your spindle with a tenths indicator on a Noga arm like so many people try to do. As soon as you put it on a sturdy holder and use a lever gauge or at least a Millimess you will see how shitty your spindle is and there's lots of roller noise and other shit going on.

>>2513610
>the bored cylinders on a fucking ferrari are more loosely toleranced than a slip fit for a bearing

They most certainly are. New run of the mill engines are pretty shit actually (at least cylinder bores) and it's totally fine. Kind of the same concept for different reasons. You COULD mic them to microns but most shops will use standard 0.01mm bore gauges because it's all you need. As soon as you put it together, mount the engine and heat it up a few degrees everything moves to shit anyway. A torque plate will easily squish a bore a few thou in some engines.

there's 3 uses of planing

1) scrubbing: removing large amounts of material off the wood's surface
2) flattening: making the surface flat
3) smoothing: making the surface smooth

The third use is a substitute for sanding and his how they did it before sandpaper become widely used. The positives are that it's very quick, efficient and even enjoyable. The downside is the large upfront cost (or time investment if you buy an antique one) and the skill required to do it well.

>>2517078
So long as the new parts are replacing those which are designed to ve replaced (ball/acme screws, bearings, etc) or something beyond repair, so long as the replacement is made of the same material and look/function identically, I don't really see the issue. I'd much rather see someone breathe new life into a 60 year old vise/saw/whatever than to let it rot away on the shelf and buy a plastic one from Walmart that'll end up in a landfill after 6 months.

Preservation of the past is not best achieved through meticulously keeping those the artifacts of the past in a static, unchanging state. History isn't something relegated to the distant past. History is happening as you read this, and you are part of it. The way I see it, there's infinitely more value in a tool passed down 3 generations that's been entirely replaced by new parts than there is in one that remained completely unchanged (and unused) for all that time.

Obviously, there are limits to this. If nothing is captured statically, then how will future generations know what the past looked like? Two answers: for one, there are things that need to be kept static. Important documents and art, for example. Those things belong in museums (on display). Your grandpa's jigsaw from the late 60s is not one of those things. If you choose not to maintain it and use it, through whatever means necessary, it will be forgotten. It becomes waste. Additionally, if you keep using artifacts of the past in the present, there's never much question as to what the past looked like, since one can look down at the tool in their hand and see the answer for themselves.

last_replies.name: Anonymous

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2514670
>I will replace the ganged 20A circuit breakers at the main junction box with two single 20A breakers.

Don't. Feed both 120V circuits from a 2 pole breaker. Two reasons 1) someone working on one leg won't open one breaker and back feed a neutral from the other side. 2) This will ensure that the two legs are fed from opposite sides of the 240 V. This will keep the neutral current below that of either leg. If not, someone might move a breaker in the future and put 40A on the common neutral. 3) It's code.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2514681
>Add a vernier readout and you can easily exceed the precision of most off-the-shelf measuring tools.

You are confusing "precision" and "resolution". You cannot get actual precision/accuracy out of this arrangement that exceeds that of the screws you used to make it. If it were that easy, actual micrometers would get away with using a rolled differential screw. In reality, even cheap micrometers just use a single, ground screw.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2517016
No. Rolled screws are surprisingly precise. They have to be or the whole "interchangeable parts" thing wouldn't work. You wouldn't be able to thread a nut all the way down a 36" piece of all-thread without it jamming. Now, are they precisely *linear*? No. They have repeating cycles of error for every X distance, where X is based on the exact tooling used. But that is easily worked around in a DIY measuring tool with calibration tests and a custom scribed scale. And cheap micrometers use a single ground screw because... surprise... it's cheaper. The economics of mass production greatly favor spending a tiny bit more on the screw vs. doing a custom calibrated scale for each unit.
>You cannot get actual precision/accuracy out of this arrangement that exceeds that of the screws you used to make it.
If that was true we would have no precision tools at all, since the first precision tools had to be created by hand at some point. In order to build the first micrometer, they had to overcome the imprecision of crudely cut threads. And it turns out that one good way to do this was... the differential screw.

Does anybody here actually, genuinely work extensively with both metric and SAE and prefer SAE? I'm looking for genuine thoughts, other than the fact that it's a front by europoors to deprive us of our freedom or whatever. I'm from northern Minnesota, but I've been doing engineering work for companies based in southern Canada for decades, so we have to use both systems interchangably. I have a few questions for those who claim their allegiance to SAE. I'm genuinely trying to understand what the hidden elegance of the SAE system is that must exist for people to like it so much.

What's up with the naming switch at 1/4" from fractional machine threads to numbered machine threads (which is confusingly identical to the entirely unrelated collection of wood/masonry/self-tapping/lag screws)? Is it because fractions below that point become unweildy? If so, I agree, but I think they're unwieldy above that point too. It seems to me like a poor imitation of the metric system.

What's up with lbm and lbf? And slugs? Having your nominal weight measurement *include* the acceleration from gravity just breaks things for no reason. Does anybody see why this is useful?

Any truly complex engineering in the SAE system is basically impossible. Every firm I know of, including ours, converts everything to metric the moment we have to do anything more complicated than a single free-body-diagram.

And then there's the more common complaints that people in this thread have already covered extensively, so I won't repeat, but I run into these every. single. day.

I'm not just trying to rip on the SAE system, I'm genuinely looking to understand why people like it so much.

>It seems to me like a poor imitation of the metric system.
Rather, those standards were made by the people developing those technologies in the first place, and different industries came up with different standards to suit their purposes (some of which reference relevant gauge sizes, which typically follow an approximately exponential relationship that breaks up a wide range of sizes into usefully distinct chunks).

>What's up with lbm and lbf?
The term "pound" was used for both situations before situations calling for differentiation become common.

>And slugs?
A slug is a unit of mass which is accelerated at one foot per second squared by a force of one pound-force acting on it.

>Does anybody see why this is useful?
Probably the people who use bathroom scales marked in kilograms rather than Newtons. For all sorts of purposes on Earth's surface, the correspondence between mass and weight makes that relationship naturally useful.

>Any truly complex engineering in the SAE system is basically impossible.
Care to give an example?

I know you're supposed to just put pavers right into the dirt but is it fine if I intend to redo it properly in a year? The worst that can happen is that the bricks just get a bit uneven right?

Alternatively: what's the laziest way to make a garden path?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
Pavers right on dirt will move and be unlevel almost immediately. Also it’s a huge pain in the ass to scrape all the mud and crap off each individual one when you go to do it right.
Larger flag stones won’t shift as easy but still the same problem with becoming unlevel over time. Also huge pain to level dirt. Much easier to just dig down a little bit, put down sharp sand, compact and screed, then lay the flagstones.
Pavers will need something to retain them like in your picture, I prefer concrete around them once laid.
If there will be heavy stuff like cars on it, you’ll need to dig deeper, put down road base, compact (ideally with a powered compactor) then thin layer of sharp sand, compact again, screed and lay. Too shallow a back fill or not enough compacting and it will get ruts.

last_replies.name: Anonymous

>>2515721
The only leather specific tools needed to make that bandolier are a stitching chisel and a hole punch for the sam browne studs. An actual pippin punch is expensive, but you can just make a round hole and add a slit with a wood chisel. Go on youtube and figure this shit out before you start buying tools though.

Skill-wise, you will want to practice your stitching a lot before you start wasting leather on projects that look like a kindergartener made them. Also the ability to sharpen things will separate professional from amateur work. A carbon steel boxcutter blade that you strop before using will serve you better than ye olde saddlers knife that you don't know how to get sharp enough to shave with.

Pull the release handle to disengage the door from the drive belt or chain.
Press the DOWN button.
If the drive operates for a bit (15 seconds) then stops, the door and drive are out of sync.
Close the door and reengage the safety release.
Now press the UP button.
Door should operate properly now.

last_replies.com: I have a tumbled limestone travertine floor, i'm extending the room, being natural stone it's all a bit different, how do I source more to match the existing,

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2516550
Unfortunately you are going to have to hunt a ton of stores and bring samples home. If there is a lot of variance between pieces on your original floor, it will be easier, but if they are a good matching set of tiles its going to be pretty difficult. Turkey, Iran and Mexico are all major suppliers of travertine, and all look a bit different. You can consider putting a threshold to break the two sides up. Grout is another factor, thoroughly clean your original grout and custom match that. I can always tell when someone added to a floor, usually from the grout, with tumbled you see a lot more grout, which may be a blessing or a curse. Try to carry grout for your new floor over to the old if you think it will help the blend.

The wrapped stuff has been tarnished (hehe) by the lazy hippie/craft fair association but wire work in general is the foundation of lots of important jewelry elements like jump rings and chains and other findings, and wire work is the most sensible place to start messing around.
Combined with hammering techniques and some basic soldering you can do some incredibly intricate things with wire, and lots of common decorative motifs seen in jewelry made by casting and stamping and other techniques are based on traditional wire filigree patterns that arent technically hard to do but are time intensive.
It's basically as complex and perfect as you want to make it and also has applications outside of jewelry and teaches some basic metallurgy stuff about work hardening, annealing, etc. for minimal investment (hoho).

com: I'm looking to build a basement bedroom for my kids and I'm wondering about moisture barriers. I just had the area waterproofed, it would get moisture in the corners before but I think that's good now. I know the walls will get moisture and condensation and I've read that the best thing to use is 2" foam boards. Also, I'm confused about whether the wall needs to "breathe" or not. last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2513683
this. if you have a fire, your kids will cook, from the top down.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2515763
You guys are saying the same thing but the child is mad lmaoooo

>>2513263
If you have actual moisture issues, putting a moisture barrier on the wall will hold moisture in the mortar and cause it to deteriorate
If your foundation is concrete, it doesn't matter
If you're masonry foundation was properly waterproofed outside the block, it doesn't matter
Most basements I've seen/worked on, leave a gap behind the wall if the moisture is questionable so a little bit of air can dissipate unwanted moisture. You put a moisture barrier on the back and front of the framed wall(with insulation in between) and you have basement that's difficult to grow mold in

The basement systems are mold-free materials so they can go on the wall without worry

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2515820
No, you're retarded, you don't need air circulation to get rid of humidity. Don't mix the problems

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2513263
Waterproofing is done outside. You dig around the perimeter of the house, lay french drains and waterproof the wall. You can also insulate on the outside with XPS boards.
Inside, I'd just keep the room well ventilated. Vapour barriers inside are used when inside air is moister than the exterior side. In this case soil is often saturated, hence the barrier outside.
The wall needs to dry on one side and it doesn't happen in undergkxdtrround soil.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2516413
I'm not saying leave feet between the wall and the foundation, I'm simply saying to not frame against the foundation if you know there's some mild moisture there

I've seen this done countless times without issue whereas when people frame up against the foundation, even the slightest bit of moisture molds.

Experience is greater than education when it comes to this shit, man.

>>2516427
Waterproofing is for sure best done outside
The only inside waterproofing is a French drain inside around the perimeter of the floor to keep the water table down. Without the xps boards, water can still penetrate the wall which I why you shouldn't frame against the foundation in this scenario

Vapor barriers are used to stop organic material from molding which is why a framed interior basement wall should have plastic on both sides so the wall is protected. With a proper seal, anything can happen between the wall and the foundation and it shouldn't matter

name: Anonymous
com:
Something I've been doing for a while in my spare time is taking apart old LCD monitors and hanging them up in front of suitable light sources eg a light-coloured wall, or curtains when the sun is shining on them. This is an old 1280x1024 LCD screen powered by a raspberry pi 3 with an HDMI to DVI cable. This monitor was a good choice for this project because it takes a 12V input from an external power brick instead of using a mains voltage "jug cord" cable. I have taken apart monitors where the power supply was powered by mains voltage, but a cable runs from the power supply PCB to the "brain" PCB (which has the video input connectors on it) and only supplies it with 12V and 5V, and it seemed to work just fine with only the 5V supplied.

The Raspberry Pi has a generic DS18B20 temperature sensor which are a couple of bucks from aliexpress so I made it shit out a text based graph, that's on the left. The top graph shows a few weeks of temperature, the bottom shows 24 hours. The terminal just updates with "tail -f graph". On the rhs it's running a digital and an analogue version of xclock.

Bash code for the temperature graphs is here-
https://pastebin.com/pq8UWyCx
This script has been used for three purposes, controlling the speed of a fan to cool a small chamber *coughgrowroomcough* to a certain temperature, controlling a heater to keep my bedroom at a certain temperature, and writing a temperature graph to be displayed with-

xterm -g 355x110+3841+1 -xrm "xterm*font:xft:DejaVu Sans Mono:size=7" -e "tail -n888 -f /mnt/graph" & { sleep .1; xterm -g 355x700-3841+1 -xrm Xft.dpi:15 -e "tail -n888 -f /mnt/graph";}
^see image

I just keep reusing it. Don't be too harsh on babby's 2nd or 3rd bash script. But was the code for constructing the graph that I thought people might be interested in, it defines colours with code like

echo -ne "\e[48:5:68m"
-e "enable escape characters"

It generates the image. Temperature of each line is the last value before the line in celcius, at the moment it draws a line every 3 hours (has been every 2 hours, every 4 hours)
